div1.head: Newspaper Clipping, The New York Times, July 11, 1901
div1.p:
The Kansas corn crop is destroyed, of
course--all burned up by hot winds and
blazing suns; and it is now known that
there will be no rain in the corn belt
until Christmas. It is shameless and
mendacious to pretend that the steel
strike can be settled or that the Atchi-
son cut rate circular will be withdrawn.
These black clouds must grow blacker
until business paralysis ensues. Gold
will go out, ice is going to be scarce and
dear, there isn't money enough to move
the crops; but that doesn't matter, for
there will be no crops to move. The
weevil has destroyed the muskmelons,
and our latest mail advices from the
Maryland terrapin beds are gloomy in
the extreme.

No stock market could long stand up
against such an accumulation of horrors.
Within a week West Shore bonds ought
to sell around 7, Sugar Trust below 10,
and St. Paul, say, at 17. In the state of
mind that has prevailed in the financial
district since the fatal May 9 these pre-
dictions probably err on the side of buoy-
ant optimism.

But we take pleasure in projecting a
solitary ray of hope across the blackened
and desolate field of investment and
speculation. There has been no death
from yellow fever in Havana since March
16. In the month of June there was not
a case of the disease, a thing that has
not been reported before since 1781--one
hundred and twenty years ago. Santiago
is free from the disease. It has not been
free from it before for 300 years.

Yellow fever usually comes to us from
Havana. Whenever it effects a lodgment
in the Southern States business is always
seriously interfered with all over the
South and in many cities and towns it is
practically suspended--sometimes as a
result of the shotgun quarantine. The
whole country feels the consequent loss
and injury to trade. New York is the
worst sufferer. It is a low estimate to
say that a visitation of yellow fever costs
the country $100,000,000. A limited and
comparatively brief interference with our
vast inter-State trade easily involves the
loss of that sum; and if the epidemic is
severe and prolonged it is much greater.

Now it is highly improbable that we
shall have any yellow fever this year--
more improbable than in any year for a
century or so. This is one of the results
of the joint despotism of WILLIAM MC-
KINLEY and LEONARD WOOD over the
Island of Cuba--whose people are and by
right ought to be free to have all the
yellow fever they want, according to the
anti-imperialists. But that is another
question and aliunde. Our present pur-
pose is to gloat over the hundred million
dollars we are going to save by not hav-
ing yellow fever this year. It is a better
human philosophy and more sensible to
exult over that than to cultivate the
hair-standing habit by poring over strike
news and cut-rate circulars.
